REVIEW: Nov 4 2007 	Location location location!	I stayed at this hotel for 3 nights at the end of October and I have to say that it is in the best location you can get in London - just a 5 minutes walk to either Picadilly Circus or Green Park (in both places you will find subway stations) and a 2 minutes walk to the bus stop where e.g. the buses leave for Knightsbridge ("Harrods") and Kensington.Many sights, shops, restaurants, ...are in walkable distance!The negative side of the location right in the city center is the fact that you hear the traffic noise in your room - also during the night. So make sure that you ask for a room on a high floor and preferably not facing one of the 2 streets. We stayed on the top floor (14th) and still could hear some traffic noise...(even with the window closed, as the glass is quite thin).The hotel itself:The hotel is modern and stylish. Nice atmosphere. Elevators did run smoothly and there was no long wait even at peak hours.The staff at the reception was very helpful and efficient.Room:The room was very nicely decorated and very clean - modern, with stylish design and seemed to be quite newly renovated.We stayed in a sup. Queen room and I have to say that the room was very small - so to make sure to have more space you should book at least the next category.The bathroom was quite large in comparison to the room and especially for London standards. The design was very modern and stylish - the only negative was that the bathroom door had a large glass element (although only partly transparent), which might not be everyones cup of tea.The view from the room was excellent as we were on the 14th floor and had a really nice view of the city.Breakfast:Was very good - large choice (from fresh fruit (ananas, ..) to salmon to porridge....). You can also order additional things from the menu which does not cost extra. Only the service was well friendly, but a bit slow.So, this hotel is a very good choice if you want a really central location and do not mind that you might hear some traffic noise during the night. This hotel offers really good quality, especially if you compare it to other hotels at the same price range in London.

Nov 26 2005	Terrific little-known luxury centrally-located hotel	I almost hate to give away this secret, but it's too good not to share: The DeVere Cavendish Hotel, at the corner of Jermyn and Duke Streets, St. James's, London, is my absolute favorite of the many 5-star London hotels in which I've stayed. We just got back from spending five nights during Thanksgiving week 2005 in one of the Cavendish's penthouse rooms, which, for GPB 220 plus tax, was a steal. The room, furnished in sleek, modern style, is a nice size, complete with a king-sized bed, a lounge chair with ottoman, a love seat, plus a television, bar cabinet and writing desk/chair. The ultra-modern bathroom has two sinks, a lovely longggg tub and a separate shower, as well as a bidet. Big towels, bathrobes, etc., are standard. It was quiet, attractive, extremely comfortable and just plain delightful. You'll have to trust me about this, because if you stop by for a quick peek, you'll be grossly unimpressed: the outside of the building is a concrete-grotesque tower, circa mid-1960's, and the lobby, while recently sporting some trendy lavender lighting behind the check-in desk and young (but professional) staff in khakis and T-shirts, is small and nothing to write home about. The hotel's value lies elsewhere than its exterior and lobby. In addition to its attractive room decor and modern bathrooms, this hotel shines in other important ways: first, location, location, location. It's a 5 - 10 minute walk to virtually every West End theatre, not to mention two tube stations. It is literally across Jermyn Street from Fortnum & Mason's, around the corner from Quaglino's, and just two blocks down from a luxurious new five-screen cinema on Regent St. Need Starbuck's coffee to survive? A quick two-minute walk around the corner takes you to Starbuck's on Piccadilly, as well as a new-ish branch of that redoubtable coffee shop, Patisserie Valerie, and the decadent mittel-European Wolseley (splendid cafe/restaurant on Piccadilly, opposite the Ritz). The other wonderful thing about the Cavendish? Well, it's the stairwell. The 15th floor penthouse rooms are reached by taking the elevator to the 14th floor and then walking up a flight of stairs to 15. In the 15th floor stairwell is one of the most amazing views of London you could ever hope to find outside the Eye. A 15-foot long picture window frames St. Paul's Cathedral, the Gherkin (Swiss Re building), St. Bride's Church, the London Eye, Parliament, Big Ben and Westminster Abbey with a mere turn of the head. Leaving aside the obvious question of why this hotel relegated the best view in the world to its stairwell, the view is fabulous during the day and astounding at night.Important point: rooms below penthouse level are also pleasant, well-furnished, and have modern bathrooms. BUT - they are much, *much* smaller. Even a "deluxe" double room, which runs, at present, GBP 170 plus tax on weekends and an additional GBP 20 on weeknights, has *just* enough room to maneuver around the bed. Non-deluxe rooms are downright tiny. But if room size doesn't bother you, request a room on a high floor on the east side of the building, and you'll get much of the stairwell view from your bed.
